The seats felt slightly crowded and the space lacked a little "something".  All and all, not bad, and they host some really creative, unusual, and interesting events here.  

My summary: the calendar would win a full 5 stars, but I'm not including that into my review.  The Stephen Petronio Yelp Event (Bloom) receives a big five stars, but I'm also not factoring that into my review.  The theatre itself walks away with a better than satisfactory four stars.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I like the spacious feel of the art museum, and they bring some interesting and eclectic artists through -- both visual and performing.

It's a cool complex with some great views of downtown throughout.

Definitely a good place to take out-of-towners (especially parental types), because it has gardens, restaurants, museums, etc.
author: Vandana M.

description:
so tiny! the first floor is currently being renovated. but fun!
my preferences lie in the way of whitney (NYC) museum worship. the oddities, the fringe, the modern, the ridiculous. 
there's a frame-tape-your-walls exhibit. there are some interesting takes on architecture, or the lack thereof. i went on free tuesday (first tuesday of the month). nothing taken, nothing left. like the whitney, no photos allowed.

i'm glad this place exists, but again, am surprised at how little it really is.

and the ad with the kid and the spaghetti -- YES!
author: Annie W.

description:
YBCA tends to have more cutting edge & local art than it's more grown up & sophisticated cousin across the street. 

The work you'll see here definitely has a more local flavor, but occasionally seems like college student work to me. 

Some installations that were particularly memorable were actually form years ago: Thomas Friedman, and also--though I can't remember the name of the artist, it was rather SRL-ish in its sheer mechanical nature: A circle of sheet metal on hydraulic lifts that popped the sheet metal leaves up at random moments. 

With memebrship you get free entry and a guest too. Oh, and in case you didn't know, I was informed that YBCA is a non-profit.
author: N B.

description:
The rain sucked but the show was fantastic.  I haven't been to a dance performance in a long time but after watching the Stephen Petronio Dance Co., I'm ready for more.  I especially liked the first half with the music of Rufus Wainright, accompanied by a girls' choir.

The theater itself was comfortable and clean and the volunteer ushers were really helpful and nice.

I didn't see any art but I will definitely go back for more exhibits and performances.
author: Seong P.

description:
The important thing to note about YBCA is that it has two distinct parts, in two different buildings, so don't forget to check them both out.  

First there's the Performing Arts Center, at 3rd & Howard, a concert hall where I had the pleasure of seeing a bizarre and esoteric Diamanda Galas concert.  

Then there's the galleries at 3rd & Mission, essentially a museum of rotating exhibits.  The current exhibit is an excellent collection of art inspired by the Dalai Lama--perfect for an urban Zen wannabe like myself.  I especially liked the video mosaic with the 120 monks saying prayers.  The mingled audio is supposed to sound like a waterfall, but to me it sounded more fitting for the last 20 minutes of 2001--an otherworldly murmur-chorus.  And the little glass-walled gallery that juts out into the street is modern design at its best.  There's also a second floor where the current exhibit is a showcase of Anna Halprin, the 87-year-old "Performance Art" pioneer.  Not really my thing so I only skimmed.  Note the little theater up here where they screen various art films.

Lastly, don't forget to take a quick stroll around the gardens after your visit, it's a great place to contemplate the profound art or theater you just saw.
author: Wes M.

description:
This review is on the galleries only.
The exhibitions can be a hit or miss so I recommend going online to see what the current exhibitions are before going. The galleries are rather small so plan on visiting the Museum of Modern Art (MOMA) across the street as well.  The Yerba Buena Gardens are a nice place to have a picnic lunch if it's a warm day.

TIPS: The galleries are free on the first Tuesday of every month.
Discounted admission to seniors, students and teachers.
author: Rachel R.

description: YBCA was a client of mine for many years and I always enjoyed their bold programming and experimental attitude. They show a tremendous range of work and whenever I visited I found fun surprises. The new "big themes" are a refreshing, thoughtful pause from the constant flow of events.
author: ari s.

description:
I came out here a few weeks back for the Dali Lama (Tenzin Gyatso with some work representing Mao Zedong) and the BioTechnique exhibits and enjoyed the collection of up and coming artist.  Some of it I had seen already in NYC already which was nice to see they getting the exposure in SF.  I was a little disappointed in the BioTechnique because several of the pieces were "not working" or unflattering as living works of art and wasn't very impressed with the background put into it.   

Regarding the space, I think it's a great size to stop in for a few hours between activities or just to hang out in the gardens but I never enjoy getting around this area, especially around the holidays. 

Definitely check it out and Thank you! for the free coat check.
author: Austin V.

description:
Almost always has an interesting exhibit/instillation. I've seen everything from Black Panthers memorabilia to old skateboards and punk records. The  actual skateboarding bowl during one exhibit was an exciting touch. 

I hate drum circles but I once caught a piece here that featured a life-sized teepee (sp?) with a circle of televisions featuring drummers. Excellent po-mo work. 

The place is so great/diverse I even got the chance to  write an article about the R. Crumb exhibit. Fabulousness.
author: Emily S.

description:
NARRATIVE
So many emails come into my inbox, but I was excited about the Art Savvy program at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in partnership with Visual Thinking Strategies (VTS) as a 101 to interpreting and understanding modern art. 

CONTACT INFORMATION
701 Mission St @ 3rd
San Francisco, CA 94103-3138
ph: 415.978.ARTS (2787)

PRICE RANGE
Free  - Decadent

SUMMARY
Yerba Buena Center for the Arts is a gem in San Francisco that is a dynamic art space. I've been there for skateboarding and hip-hop exhibits, youth film festivals, theater and dance performances.

Their Art Savvy program is a once a month program to introduce community members to modern art through the use of Visual Thinking Strategies. By partnering with VTS, YCBA opens the gallery on a Thursday evening. Participants are guided through a discussion of a variety of pieces to open up the sensibility to modern pieces. (Which is great if you are not an expert.) Afterward, we are led through the gallery's current show and spend about an hour responding to the pieces as a group.

Great way to spend an evening and approach modern art in a completely non-pretentious way. The facilitators really were helpful in sharing their knowledge with the participants. Participants ranged from working artists/educators to novices, such as myself, who may have a sense of aesthetics, but lack formal training in "capital A" art.

December 2008's exhibit featured works from Viet Nam and Korea. It is "transPOP: Korea Vietnam Remix."

SERVICE
YCBA and VTS staff were excellent facilitators for the evening. We had a separate classroom for the "instructional" portion of the session and then went down into the gallery space to view some of the work. 

They were really encouraging of participation, offered their expertise, but also elicited the knowledge of the participants to create an impression of the works.


RESTROOMS
Lovely restrooms at the YCBA.

SUGGESTION
Art Savvy is an excellent idea! Perhaps each month targets specific groups? Professionals, students, youth, artists, dancers, techies, etc. to get their take on art and to also open the space up to more community members.
author: Eriqua P.

description:
i really enjoyed going here a couple couple couple years back. ive been wanting to come back SO much, but no one ever wants to accompany me :(. well upon my last experience! Though  it was amazing it is a modern art museum, they were able to capture all the essence of art anyways. 

they had a whole display from this one artist that made all these different pieces from an orange. there were orange peels hanging everywhere and shaped and molded into different forms. 

Then there was a whole bunch of surfboards all over the exhibit with different illustrations all over it. 

i know they had a whole bunch of other stuff, but i cant remember. 
but the one thing that got me the most was definitely the exhibit with the oranges.
author: fionion f.

description:
This is an awesome place, no doubt, but I find the exhibits here hit-or-miss.  You have to consider the building itself is not all that big and they *do* manage to put on great exhibitions in spite of it.  I would say to definitely watch the calendar to see what is going on.

Times visited: 3+
author: Amy L.

description:
Very compelling art exhibits! The two exhibitions were based on Vietnam and Korea with their relation to the Vietnam war and greenifying urban space. The piece with Vietnamese people retelling their encounters with helicopter's destruction and symbol of national pride during the war was very moving. 

Throughout the gallery, you use your cell phone to hear the meaning behind certain pieces, which was neat. It would be even better if they had daily exhibition tours since they tend to make everything 10x more meaningful. 

Outside the museum is a gorgeous garden with a lovely inspiring water features. Who can complain about that?
author: Wing P.

description:
SFMOMA rocks it, but for some truly contemporary art particularly art from the Bay Area, the Yerba Buena Center rocks the Casbah. One of the best series they have is the Bay Area Now shows. It features some of the best emerging artists of the Bay Area (including Neck Face!!!). This is also where you can find awesome off-beat shows like "Beautiful Losers", the Erwin Wurm exhibit and the Creative Growth show. 

Some of the best curatorial work in San Francisco is done here. The shows have a great flow to them and the space is excellent for the work both large and small scale.
author: Jackie I.

description:
Five stars for this wonderful performing arts space and garden. The events I've attended here:

Live Dangerously: An evening celebrating freedom of expression with SF poet laurette's reading Alan Ginsberg's poem Howl and displaying the censored works of Lawrence Ferlenghetti

Israel in the Gardens: A whole day festival outside with music, food and local businesses celebrating Israel's 60th Anniversary.

Breaks: Marc Bamuthi Joseph's multimedia performance - tribute to hip hop and revisits themes of dual consciousness, identity/ self discovery and expression.  Preeminent hip hop artist and essential performer / educator of our time.
author: Jessica M.

description: If it is still on at the time you read the review....... check out the fake handbag exhibit. .......So clever.
author: Brendan R.

description: I loved going to the porn flicks screening last year from CineKink festival, for some reason I didn't hear about it this year and missed it. Anyway, I went to the What's the Big Idea? Night Party 2009, and it was horrible. Pure lame. Displays/ "ART" were absolutely boring and amateur, music was trash (where was the Cuban band?) nobody was dancing, some security people were rude. I am giving it 3 stars because this is their first party and they were offering free (real) tattoo's and free cover charge. No henna though like they claimed to have.  The patio was nice and that's where most hung out.  I'd rather they charged 5-10 bucks and do a better job in this venue, it's a waste of precious space and potential positive ambiance here.
author: Celine H.

description:
Yesterday I was lucky enough to get to go see the Stephen Petronio Company performance at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. I've been here before, but only to the galleries, where I have seen some pretty amazing art shows. This event was in the beautiful performance space, and was one of the most amazing performances I have seen. There were three pieces in all, each one with its own amazing lighting, music, costuming, and especially wonderful choreography and music. I was so excited to be there, and everything was above and beyond any expectations I had. The dancers were incredible, especially the soloist that performed near the end. I really really loved every part of it.
The middle piece, I think it was called Bloom, had some very covetable music, by Rufus Wainright and the female dancers were wearing the cutest dresses. All my friends and I agreed that we would love to be in possession of the dresses and the music! 
If anyone gets a chance, I would suggest seeing a performance here, or the Stephen Petronio Company, wherever they may be performing.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: The exhibit on Mexican street graphics was simply outstanding. All kinds of signage, lettering, paintings. All hand done, yet with exquisite attention to detail--or if not, at least a very refined sense of sloppiness. The show setup seemed improvised, with a lot of work hanging on wooden dividers. But this totally fit with the mood. I didn't even check out the rest of the center, because I have a time limit on how much art I can absorb--anything more than an hour and my brain reels from too much stimuli.
author: Patrick G.

description: Checked out the Big Idea night party. Free entrance, modern exhibits and bhangra music 'til midnight? I'm there!
author: Celeste P.

description: The opening parties are too much of a scene for my tastes. A real distraction for art lovers trying to avoid a singles party.
author: Philip M.

description: Dude, the seats are so close that I could smell what people ate for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Joking aside, it is a wonderful place to go to see amazingly talented people. The location is perfect as it is right across the street from the SF MOMA. So, you can always pay the center a visit before or after you get your artsy fix. The YBCA is another reason to get more involved with the community as well. Many of the events held bring in people that you wouldn't normally meet and to find commonalities facilitated by the activities and events from one place -- definitely deserves 5 stars.
author: Dorothy S.

description: YBCA, what can I say.  This has been my employer for the last 6yrs and it holds a very special place in my heart.  I have gone from working as a preparator to the administration offices and I feel as though I have grown with this organization.  We are always questioning the boundaries of art and concept.  For a long time I only attended the galleries, but since I've started working closer to the other curators I have found myself attending many more wonderful performances and off the wall films.  If you haven't been here yet I don't know where you've been, but I would suggest widening your horizons by attending more of our mind tickling events.
author: Wren C.

description:
i dont have any grandparents. never did. so when i need a fix of old people i go to art events on sundays. and im not being agest. im completely serious. its like a portal into a generation i will never really come close to. so i lurk with the seniors. so what. im weird.

today is mothers day. took my mom here cause she likes this piece.

carmenina burana with modern ballet on a sunday afternoon. wicked.

this was after i gave my mom a salt lamp and a blue and yellow shiny scarf.

 it was worth taking the 6 downtown and smelling all the foulness. 

i felt underdressed in my hoodie and flip flops but fuck it, its a sunday.

nice box office guy.
author: coffeecake j.

description: If you're looking for truly modern art, stuff that pushes the limits and boundaries, YBCA is the place. They have a great performance and film series, plus some kick-ass opening parties as well!
author: Nish N.

description: I've only been inside here once years ago to check out a hip hop exhibit. It seemed to be okay but from what I can remember, it was nothing spectacular. There are definitely better museums/art centers in San Francisco to visit besides this one. I would go again though definitely..and when I do, I will update!
author: Lynn C.

description: Sweet little theater in which to see performances & art shows. I've seen ODC here before and a ballet. In the summertime they put on free lunchtime shows in the gardens, it's always a great time! Last year I saw a Rosa Parks homage dance thing with teenage girls, they were so talented!
author: Colleen B.

description: We saw Rachel Maddow here, who deserves 10 stars herself.  YBCA was a nice, new space - modern, but cozy. There were quite a substantial nubmer of chairs in rows in a big auditorium.  As comfortable as chairs fastened together can be. Was a lovely evening, but I would have thought seeing Maddow in a sewer would have been a lovely evening.
author: Emily M.

description: Consistently excellent curation, and a beautiful contemporary space make this one of my favorite places to while away a rainy Sunday afternoon.. The Opening night parties are possibly my favorite art party in the city.
author: Stellah D.

description: The BF and I caught a Cypress String Quartet performance here.  Reasonable acoustics but they were recording and had a weird mic setup that made it feel like the performers were in another room.  Also, they gave away a lot of tickets to school groups which is admirable but I think about half of them had TB based on the coughing.
author: Kevin S.

description: A great space for contemporary art, unusually exhibitions that are small but extraordinary.  It's also nice to go to a museum where you don't have to fight the crowd and feel their breath over your shoulder.  Definitely worth checking out when the entrance is free on the 1st Tuesday of the month for all and the 1st weekend of the month for Bank of America customers.
author: S. I.

description: Super fun and free on 1st tuesdays.  I really feel like they are on the bleeding edge and I love them.
author: Monera M.

description: The seats are narrow with hardly any legroom and sound wasn't consistent both times I've been there - I expect better from such a new facility.
author: Quartknee K.

description:
i saw the ballet here and it was perfect. everyone is very sweet and i think it's best to  sit  in  the front row on the terrace so you can see the music.  

on the way in tonight there was a man outside selling his poetry for  five dollars. if you can, buy it before  you go in.
author: aerin w.

description:
Went to party
With luchadors and drag queens
Also there was art?
author: Balboa C.

description: I went to YBCA for the Nick Cave sound suits performance and I was really inspired by the way the space welcomed such an unusually fanciful, comfortable  and also raucous event.  I saw a lot of people I know there which is always great--especially when its random and unexpected.  But truly, the suits are so ornate and delicious to look at.  I loved watching the dancers make their way through the crowd and watching the crowd respond to the dancers.  So glad YBCA hosted all this.
author: Ariel W.

description: I've seen so many great things here, Stephen Petronio Dance Company, Paul Taylor, Cullberg Ballet, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Batsheva and most recently Pappa Tarahumara. Five stars for any place that brings in great and diverse independent art!
author: Cathy T.

description:
Come here to see Nick Cave's ornate, gorgeous creations.  They're testaments to the imagination in the form of heffalumps, weird sequined yetis with anthropomorphic reed carriages, beavers with mittens building a sweater-noodle-dam, intricate beadwork on amorphous giants, headdresses made out of doilies, and general shininess everywhere.  (Oddly enough, the photographs and videos of the soundsuits also hold their own, even when you've got the real things right there.)

I actually saw the Nick Cave exhibition at the "What's the Big Idea?" party.  Attend a party here.  Just...wow.  I arrived at around midnight so I missed a lot of the performances, but I caught the end of some aerial acrobatics.  I got to see a bit of the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence with their punk-vampire-drag act, gurgling fake blood and being generally amazing.   My favorite was one of the backup singers: whitefaced, with strange clown-diamond abysses for eyes and an unnatural cock to the head, spewing blood from the mouth and then smearing it on his own face.  And that was just the beginning.

Half the fun is checking out what other attendees are wearing.  One guy, completely spangled in silver sequins, told us he was a superhero raising money to "remove the self-loathing from children in a beam."  Yeah, that's an exact quote, but he got a couple of bucks out of us to take a picture with him because he looked like a magpie's nest AND spoke in a robot voice.  

And as we were standing on the street outside after exiting the party, we saw a guy striding by grumbling and strewing tinsel (????) behind him, like a disaffected elf.  A fitting ending to a night at YBCA.
author: S P.

description: This is a great museum with an ever-changing host of artists and exhibitions. You will always find some cutting-edge and thought-provoking works here. It's a convenient location and the price is quite reasonable. They also have the service where you can call on your cell phone to find out about the works.
author: Ryan C.

description: I like the building, but I think they could stand to curate better exhibits. And their Big Idea party was nice.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Such a great place in the city.
-wonderful galley exhibits
-amazing dance performances
-interesting films
-live theater (xoxo)
-beautiful gardens

A fantastic resource for parents with young children.
author: A W.

description: Right next to MOMA but much cheaper.  Don't let that fool you, this little museum searches for only the best, most relevant work and, at that price, aims to make it accessible to everyone.  We need more museums with this spirit and attitude towards bringing important art to more people.
author: Rob M.

description: I went to see Cosmic Wonder/Sampling Oakland last week courtesy of Yelp. Also because of the 2 for 1 deal, I got a few friends to jump on the bandwagon! Some of the art was mesmerizing with detail and unusual media. However, I'd between my group of 7, only a few us actually thought the art was something "great."
author: Anita C.

description: YBCA is by far one of the most innovative and energetic performance venues open to the public in SF. After a year and a half of a steady diet of their brand of art, I now blindly buy tickets for anything and everything they offer. I am never disappointed. Fantastic, inventive, engaging, powerful, funny, global and professional on every level. We are so lucky to have access to them. Best art membership in the Bay Area!
author: Monster B.

description: Love this very versatile center. Ice skating ! The Zeum ! Theatre! There are so many things to do here.
author: Sophie D.

description: YBCA is such an amazing venue to see live performance in SF.  There's a great view from any seat in the house, although I'd avoid the boxes if you're seeing dance - the perspective's a little wonky.  I especially recommend checking out the "YBCA Presents" series - these are performers from around the world that Yerba Buena finds and makes it possible for them to come to San Francisco.  BTW, subscribing to a series makes the tickets super cheap.
author: Wendy M.

description: Good venue space. I came here for one of the yelp holiday parties and I was impressed the YBCA was bigger than expected. I was able to look at some exhibits and I would agree that this has more interested stuff than the SF MOMA. I think they also gave free tickets for another visit too (that don't expire ever), so that was pretty generous.
author: Retired B.

description: I was here twice a week at least when the Beautiful Losers / Free Basin exhibit was running late last year.  It was in a word incredible!  The artwork, the photography, sculpture all were top notch especially the Free Basin skateboard bowl.  I applaud the museum for their efforts in this project!  I just wish they'd build another bowl inside for me to skate!
author: Derek D.

description: I recently went to a Design Series lecture here and the speaker - Clodagh - was just magnificent! Her presence, knowledge and spirit surrounding interior design and life was just mesmerizing. Great job by Yerba Buena for the presentation and subject!
author: Amanda P.

description: This is a great institution that has really good activities in addition to its museum.  Recently I participated in their gallery walk which was 6 smaller galleries in the vicinity that opened up their spaces for free.  There was wine and appetizers and the art was diverse, interesting and in some cases very affordable.
author: Gwyneth T.

description: I saw the HMS Pinafore here, a Gilbert & Sullivan Production, during my stay in San Francisco. It was an absolutely delightful night! Hilarious and entertaining, I would love to see it again! Very well-done and great actors!
author: S. F.

description: YBCA! My favorite!  I've seen so many great exhibits here - the Beautiful Losers show, The Royal Art Lodge, Cosmic Wonder......the list goes on. And the films series are amazing.  My message to the film curator: "I love you!"  I've also seen some great music there - the Asha Boshle with the Cronos Quartet, Diamanda Galas to mention just a couple.
author: Super H.

description: An appealing place to relax with a great view of the skyline in middle of SOMA
author: Joey C.

description:
-there's something sexay about a boy who knows his public transportation. if you're bad at direction like i am, there's nothing better than a man leading your way
-watani and i decide to go to SF all thru some footaction and public transpo with the goal to go to YBCA and use the pass i got from the yelp christmas bash '07
-i love walking, i am thankful someone does too and is down
-we go in and leave our touristy backpacks at the front desk as our tickets were issued
-we were greeted pleasantly.... seemed like almost all the security/guides were my "kababayan"s
-art always moves me, since i am hyper and can't keep still, doesn't mean i don't run thru my head the kazillion possiblilties of what, if and how, or just plain wow
-laying flat on our backs on the cushions looking up at some sliding photography bout 3 feet infront of us from a flat screen dangling from the ceiling was great and somewhat romantic
-the "psycho room" (was going thru my head) was awesome.....felt like i was in the movie hostel and they were sharpening the tool of choice for my demise below me as i feel the vibrations, hear the sounds and see the passing lights from the cracks on the floor
-i remember the restrooms from the xmas party....very vital knowing how my bladder gets, clean...both upstairs (1 person) and down (a few stalls)
-the peephole grass carpet walkway was fun, esp. with the people outside looking at you thru the glass like you were on crack. watani: i don't get it (as he sticks his head into a hole)....
me: dood.....there's no peephole in that one.
-the vibrating buttocks, penis and boobage was a little bit surprising but i so wanted to womanhandle them so i just turned around and moved toward the room with "the book".
-too much awesomeness to mention, it was fun times with great company.
-focus on local......gotta love that
-thelma, one of the gracious guides told us it's FREE EVERY 2'ND TUESDAY! go! go! go!
-while enjoying the sight of the lush gardens from the inside i recognized someone as i knock on the glass and get his attention with an invisible blow .....cobber san lucas! awwww he joined us for a few in the spacious lobby and walked out with us
=PPPSSSSSTTT, CAN I HAVE YOUR PASS IF YOU STILL HAVE IT? THANK YOU YELP FOR GREAT FREE SHIEYT!
author: serbelle i.

description:
i love art.
it's that simple and ybca satisfies.... you're not going to get your rockstar shows here (wait, beautiful losers, well, and fela kuti, oh and the rank and file : black panthers show : and i guess the whole bay area now cult), well, it's more accessible rockstar, without the limos and beefy security teams. security here is volunteer docents from the suburbs on opening night, really, really, really determined to stop you from taking that picture of that AMAZING poster "by any means available" while 4 OTHER PEOPLE! are posing next to the weird native sculpture....!
oh, but back to the (he)art.....
great venue, excellent curatorial team, relevant shows to the bay area, lots of natural light, really quite friendly security, great staff that makes that place happen! and WORKING ARTIST memberships. big deal, folks! 
opening night parties are slamming everytime and you CAN see the art, be patient, and 100s of beautiful people as well, and i promise you'll run into at least 3 you know personally.
don't forget the first tuesdays of the month are free, and finally, they keep a rotating exhibition schedule, so there will be art either in the upstairs galleries or downstairs galleries, but really, you want both... check the website before you head out
author: Scatha G.

description: first visit was okay. they had closed a bunch of the galleries though, so i couldn't have a much fuller experience. will visit again though.
author: Kenneth H.

description: This is a great spot and could be a great theater. I just wish there was more!  For some reason I used to attend events here all the time years ago and then not so much.  The Steve Petrionio event was fantastic.
author: Misti L.

description: i love forum at ybca; it's an excellent space for dance. it's intimate in feel, and every seat is a good seat. this is the place to go for regional, national, and international dance that's looking forward towards what's possible and beyond.
author: Bee H.

description: spending a saturday night at the YBCA made me feel like a tru culture vulture.  seong p and i braved the rain last night to check out the stephen petronio dance co, and it was great.  what dance troupe wouldn't be great when moving to the music of rufus wainwright?  god, i love him.  anyhow, definitely come check out other shows as well, such as the ODC shows, which are always great!  i'm not really into the classical musical performances, but there are always great dance companies that come thru here!
author: Helen T.

description: I went to the Cosmic Wonder opening last night with two of my roommates and I'm still trying to digest the entire experience.  There was quite a few interesting exhibits, like the television showing a continuous video of various other televisions.  And there was also the television surrounded by grocery store items, showing a video of a shopping cart traveling through a grocery store with nobody pushing it.  And I can't forget the large room where the drinks we're being served....I watched a man dressed in head to toe neon dance around doing violent movements as he tried to expel fear from the room to the ringtones of the Dirty South's very own -- Bone Crusher.  If you're confused, so was I?  The Cosmic Wonder exhibit  was the epitome of freedom of expression and seemed to fit perfectly in the fine city of San Francisco.  The technology was state of the art and the place was very spacious and the prints and performanes were interesting to say the least..  I'd definitely go back for future exhibits.
author: LaSha G.

description: i give out only a few 5 star reviews. this place gets one of them. what a fantastic space for taking in arts/culture, food and r&r.  they have a great theater program, cool cafes with views of the city, and a fantastic lawn that also serves as a the summer time music series concert ground.  modern, refreshing and clean. should be on everyone's list of to-do's several times a year.
author: Kevin J.

description: it's the place where i work, and also the place where i fell in-love with the arts. from independent films to bowl skaters to ballet, we have em all! the people that works here will always go way and beyond the call of duty and will support you in every aspect of your life. This place rocks!
author: Joremel A.
